title: Open Tibial Fracture
diagnosis_topic: Gustilo grade II open tibia fracture from motorcycle accident
setup_script: A 30-year-old man has a deformed right lower leg after a motorcycle crash. Bone is visible through a wound on the anteromedial shin. He is otherwise healthy.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 130/75 mmHg, HR 98 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 37 C.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident performs assessment of the extremity
dynamic_flow.reply: 5 cm laceration exposing tibial shaft, moderate contamination with dirt, palpable pedal pulses, intact sensation.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident administers IV antibiotics (cefazolin and gentamicin) within one hour
If resident covers wound with sterile saline-soaked dressing and stabilizes with temporary splint
dynamic_flow.reply: Protects tissue and minimizes further injury.
Comminuted mid-shaft tibial fracture with minimal comminution.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults orthopedics for irrigation and debridement
dynamic_flow.reply: Taken to OR within 6 hours for debridement and external fixation.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays antibiotics or debridement

dynamic_flow.reply: Grade I: <1 cm wound; Grade II: 1-10 cm; Grade III: >10 cm or high energy with severe soft tissue damage.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about definitive fixation
dynamic_flow.reply: Convert to internal fixation after soft tissue condition improves.
Early range of motion and weight-bearing when safe; physical therapy.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident evaluates for compartment syndrome
dynamic_flow.reply: Monitor pain, sensory changes and pulses postoperatively.

critical_decision_points: Early antibiotic administration and tetanus prophylaxis in open fractures
Soft tissue assessment and Gustilo classification
Monitoring for infection and compartment syndrome
Planning for definitive fixation and rehabilitation
